issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: DataXceiver tries to establish secure channels via sasl when dfs.encrypt.data.transfer is turned on. However, domain socket traffic seems to be unencrypted therefore the client cannot communicate with the data node via domain sockets, which makes short circuit reads unfunctional.
fields.summary: Short circuit reads fail when dfs.encrypt.data.transfer is enabled

comments.body:
This is a good find.  Thanks, Haohui.

I believe that UNIX domain sockets should ignore {{dfs.encrypt.data.transfer}}.  Because UNIX domain sockets are local (they never leave the same machine), there is no concern about network snooping as there is with TCP connections.  Encryption would not add any real security in this context.  This is especially true when passing file descriptors, since in that case, none of the data is going through the socket anyway.
I am going to mark this as blocker for 2.3.0

  http://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12610941/HDFS-5353.001.patch
  against trunk revision .

The patch looks good to me. The only comment I have is that it might be better to move some of the javadoc in DomainPeer#hasSecureChannel() to Peer#hasSecureChannel().

+1 once this is addressed.
btw, there's trailing whitespace in the patch. You might want to fix it when you update the patch.
